An online obituary claimed Rossi died on this date, which turned out to be a deception used to evade arrest, revealing his pattern of fraud and flight.

keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008.
Rossi faked his death in 2020 by claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which led to a false obituary and allowed him to evade capture for years.
He was identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit, part of Utah’s effort to clear its rape kit backlog.
He was arrested in Scotland in 2023 while receiving treatment for COVID-19, recognized by hospital staff through distinctive tattoos, including a Brown University crest.
He used multiple aliases, including 'Arthur Knight,' to evade law enforcement and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
Rossi was convicted in two separate cases: one in August 2025 and another in September 2025, with sentencing in both cases.
The victim described the abuse as involving financial manipulation, coercion, and a pattern of control, including asking her to pay for dates and take on debt for engagement rings.
The case highlights the dangers of false death claims and the importance of DNA evidence in solving old rape cases.
Utah law allows prison sentences as a range — in this case, five years to life — with parole decisions made by a parole board.
Rossi maintained his innocence during sentencing, claiming the victims were lying and appeared in court using a wheelchair and oxygen tank.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was sentenced to five years to life in prison by a Utah judge after being convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. Rossi faked his death in 2020, claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which misled authorities and allowed him to evade arrest for years. He was identified through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog, and later arrested in Scotland in 2023 due to recognition of his distinctive tattoos, including a Brown University crest. He used multiple aliases, including 'Arthur Knight,' to conceal his identity. Both victims testified, describing financial manipulation and abusive behavior, including requests for money and debt for engagement rings. Prosecutors argued Rossi posed a danger to public safety, while his lawyers urged parole. This case underscores the impact of DNA testing in clearing old cases and the dangers of false death claims by individuals with criminal histories.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
